Jiangsu Province Engineering Research Center of Fine Utilization of Carbon Resources, China University of Mining & Technology Xuzhou Jiangsu 221116 China Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin to value-added biofuels and chemicals has a great significance for the advanced utilization of renewable lignocelluloses and the future biobased economy but is always a big challenge. Herein, a Ga-doped HZSM-5 supported metal Ru catalyst (bifunctional Ru/Ga-HZSM-5) exhibited the excellent HDO performance for converting diphenyl ether (DPE) to produce the only product, i.e., cyclohexane, under extremely mild conditions (180 °C, 1 MPa H2 and 2 h). The oxygen-containing group in DPE was mainly removed through the cleavage of the C-O ether bond, followed by metal- and acid-catalyzed comprehensive hydrogenation and deoxygenation. Further characterization results confirmed that the doping of Ga remarkably enhanced the interaction between the metal Ru and the support. For the depolymerization of real lignin, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 could not only significantly improve the total liquid yield of lignin, but also convert the oxygen-containing species into the aliphatic hydrocarbons. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Hydrodeoxygenation Lignin Diphenyl ether Ru Ga HZSM-5 1 Introduction Obtaining value-added fuels and chemicals from renewable energy resources is the most important step to effectively solve some existing issues about environmental pollution and energy crisis [1–3]. As the main component of lignocellulosic biomass, lignin is regarded as an important and sustainable source of the most abundant aromatics, phenolics and alkanes in nature [4–7]. A large number of stable C-O bonds and C-C bonds are present in the molecular structure of lignin, especially the high content of C-O bonds, which limit the direct depolymerization of lignin to produce the low-molecular-weight compounds [8–10]. Selective cleavage of C-O bonds represents a crucial route to achieve the depolymerization of lignin. Among different types of depolymerization techniques, hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is one of the most effective strategies to convert lignin and its model compounds to high-quality oxygen-free biofuels and chemicals [11–13]. The bond dissociation energy of 4-O-5 ether in lignin structure is the largest, as represented by the typical diphenyl ether (DPE), so that it’s difficult to undergo the HDO reaction under mild conditions [14,15]. The catalysts play a key role in this process. It is still a significant challenge to design and develop the highly active and selective catalysts for achieving the HDO of lignin. In the development of reduction methods for the lignin-to-hydrocarbon process, the most commonly used catalysts mainly include three types: (i) transition/precious metal-based catalysts; (ii) metal oxide catalysts; (iii) traditional sulfide catalysts, different metal carbide, nitride and phosphide catalysts [16–19]. Among them, the metal-based catalysts used in form of metal have received much attention from researchers due to their unique structure and high activity. Compared with transition metals, precious metals with the higher activity tend to perform better in special reactions [20–22]. Ru metal which has a lower price than other precious metals such as Pd and Rh, has a better industrial application prospect [23]. In addition to metals, the supports are also an important part of metal-supported catalysts. Particularly, the HDO reaction requires not only the active sites such as metals where the hydrogenation can undergo, but also the acid sites that are responsible for the removal of oxygen [24,25]. Therefore, the dual-functional metal catalysts containing Brønsted acid sites of zeolite and Lewis metal sites are one of the most interesting candidates for promoting the HDO of lignin and its model compounds [26]. A series of metals supported on HZSM-5 has been intensively investigated to evaluate as the catalysts for various systems of HDO. For example, Zhang et al. [27] reported that the bifunctional zeolite supported metal Ru catalyst (Ru/HZSM-5) could effectively catalyze the HDO of lignin model compounds to produce alkane fuels. Luo et al. [28] have successfully developed the hydrothermally stable Ru/HZSM-5 as the catalysts for the selective hydrogenolysis of lignin-derived substituted phenols to bio-arenes in water. Despite current achievements in the HDO of lignin model compounds, the excellent catalysts working under mild conditions are still challenging. It is well established that the HDO of oxygenated compounds is usually carried out under a high temperature (200–450 °C) and a high H2 pressure (4–5 MPa), especially when Ru is used as the active site [26,27,29–32]. Considerable research efforts have been devoted to improve the catalytic performance such as the utilization of bimetallic catalyst [26]. Recently, the important principle of the strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) in heterogeneous catalysis gradually enters the vision of researchers to improve the activity, selectivity and stability of supported catalysts [33–35]. This effect generally occurs on metal and easily reducible oxide supports such as CeO2, SnO2 and TiO2. Ga2O3 has received a wide attention due to its superior catalytic performance. For instance, the highly efficient bimetallic Ga-doped Cu/H-nanozeolite-Y (Cu/HNZY) catalyst was prepared successfully for the selective hydrogenation and HDO of lignin model compounds under mild conditions, as studied by Verma et al. [36]. The Pt-Ga-mesoporous catalysts exhibited the good performance for the HDO of guaiacol [37]. However, as a stable and difficultly reducible oxide, Ga2O3 is frequently ignored in the selection of SMSI support [38]. Herein, based on SMSI, we designed a Ga-doped HZSM-5 supported metal Ru catalyst (Ru/Ga-HZSM-5). The Ga element was used to enhance the interaction between Ru and HZSM, thereby optimizing the catalyst structure and improving the catalytic performance. Finally, the relationship between the activity and the structure of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was explored as well. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation and characterizations The Ga-doped HZSM-5 support was synthesized by a hydrothermal method. According to a molar composition of SiO2: 0.011 Al2O3: 0.15 TPAOH: 30 H2O: 0.01 Ga(NO3)3·5H2O, a certain amount of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt%), NaAlO2 and Ga(NO3)3·5H2O were mixed in deionized water, subsequently stirred for 1 h at room temperature. And then tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) was added into the mixture under vigorous stirring for 2 h at room temperature. After that, the resulting gel was transferred directly into a Teflon-88 lined stainless-steel autoclave to be crystallized at 160 °C for 72 h. The precipitations were washed with deionized water to neutrality and calcined at 550 °C for 10 h. H-form zeolite could be obtained by ion-exchange with 1 M NH4Cl labeled as Ga-HZSM-5. The corresponding HZSM-5 support was synthesized by using the same method except for the introduction of Ga(NO3)3·5H2O in the system. All Ru-based catalysts investigated in the HDO reactions were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation with the corresponding supports. In a typical preparation process of 5% Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, 1 g Ga-HZSM-5 was added to appropriate amount of RuCl3 aqueous solution. After stirring and ultrasound, the mixture was deposited in a vacuum box for 24 h. Subsequently, the solution was dried at 105 °C overnight, followed by calcination under Ar atmosphere and reduction under H2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 3 h, respectively. 5% Ru/HZSM-5, 5% Ru/SiO2 and 5% Ru/γ-Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the same method. These catalysts were well characterized by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm measurements, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopic (HAADF-STEM). The detail materials, catalyst preparation and characterization methods were listed in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Catalytic reaction The HDO reactions were all performed in a 100 mL stainless-steel autoclave at a magnetic stirring rate of 800 rpm. Typically, the substrate, catalyst and solvent were together added in the reactor. After purging the reactor for three times with H2, the outlet valve was closed to maintain the desired pressure at ambient temperature and heated to the desired temperature. The heating rate was around 10 °C/min. After the reaction was halted, the reactor was naturally cooled to room temperature and decompression. Obtained liquid products were collected and analyzed by gas chromatograph-mass spectrometer (GC-MS) and gas chromatograph (GC). The separated catalyst was washed with the solvent and dried at 50 °C under vacuum condition for the direct use in next cycle experiment. All experimental results are reproducible. The carbon balance in the liquid phase was better than 95 ± 3% in this work. The carbon selectivity (C%), substrate conversion and product selectivity were calculated as the following formulas. (1) C selectivity = moles of product × the number of C moles of substrate reacted × the number of C in substrate × 100 ( % ) (2) Conversion = moles of substrate reacted total moles of substrate × 100 % (3) Selectivity = moles of each product (bicyclic × 2 , monocyclic × 1 ) total moles of each product (bicyclic × 2 , monocyclic × 1 ) × 100 % (4) Relative peak area = Peak area of identified product Peak area of all products × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization As shown in Fig. 1a, the samples showed a combination of both type-I and type-IV isotherms with an obvious hysteresis loop [39,40]. It implied that many mesopores and micropores were mainly distributed in these materials, possessing the narrow pore distribution with a range from 0 to 4 nm, as shown in Fig. 1b. The detailed porous structure data of these samples were summarized in Table 1. Similar total specific surface area, total pore volume and average pore diameter were present in prepared Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5. With the addition of Ru metal, the surface area, pore volume and pore diameter in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5 all decreased slightly compared with corresponding Ga-HZSM-5 and HZSM-5. This result was confirmed from the pore size distributions in Fig. 1b that the curves of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5 shifted to lower values than Ga-HZSM-5 and HZSM-5. Compared to other oxide supports, zeolite materials with a large specific surface area could ensure a uniform distribution of active metal Ru. As described in Fig. 2, all samples showed the typical crystalline phase of HZSM-5 [41,42]. Both Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5 demonstrated characteristic Bragg reflections at 2θ of 38.4°, 44.2°,44.0°, 58.3° and 69.4° attributed to a Ru phase of the lattice planes of (100), (002), (101), (102) and (110), respectively. The weak characteristic peaks of metal Ru confirmed that Ru was distributed uniformly on the support surface and Ru particles were extremely small [28]. In the case of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ga-HZSM-5 samples, XRD patterns showed the characteristic reflections at 2θ of 30.8°, 36.2°, 44.1°, 54.6°, 58.4°, 64.2° and 76.1°, which were indexed to (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440) and (533) planes of Ga2O3 phase, respectively. The peak intensity of Ga2O3 was also very weak, revealing that Ga was uniformly dispersed in the framework of in-situ synthesized Ga-HZSM [37]. Although the diffraction peaks of Ru in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5 were both weak, further observation showed that the peak intensity of metal Ru in Ru/HZSM-5 was slightly stronger than that in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. It might be possible that the addition of Ga promoted a better dispersion of Ru nanoparticles that cannot be detected by XRD and the same tendency occurred in the literature [36,37]. The catalytic component of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was the reduced metal Ru instead of oxides of Ru and Ga. As shown in Fig. 3a and Table 2, the acidity distribution from the experimental TPD curve could be divided into three different regions, in which the three peaks represented the weak (T < 300 °C), midstrength (300 °C < T < 500 °C) and strong (T > 500 °C) acid sites, respectively [43,44]. The predominance in Ru/γ-Al2O3 and Ru/SiO2 was the weak and strong acid sites, respectively, while the midstrength acid site was dominant in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5. According to the previous report [45], the midstrength acid site was responsible for the HDO process. Obviously, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 possessed the largest amount of the midstrength acid site among these catalysts, confirming the best HDO performance for DPE. Fig. 3b depicted that only one distinct reduction peak was observed in each curve, which was ascribed to the reduction of RuO2 species to metal Ru [46,47]. The reduction temperature in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was determined at around 151 °C while a lower reduction temperature around 137 °C was present in Ru/HZSM-5. The shift of the reduction peak to a higher temperature suggested that the addition of Ga could enhance the interaction between Ru and HZSM-5, which hindered the reduction of RuO2 [48–51]. No other peaks appeared in the temperature range studied, indicating that Ga element existed in the form of Ga oxide [38]. Previous literature [52,53] also revealed that Ga2O3 need to be reduced above 800 °C under H2 atmosphere. During the in-situ synthesis of Ga-HZSM-5, Ga replaced part of Al sites and was stably distributed in the framework of HZSM-5. As shown in Fig. 4, all the binding energies were corrected by C 1s at 284.8 eV of C-C. Since Ru0 3d3/2 peak around 284.8 eV was overlapped with C 1s, it was difficult to identify the binding energy of Ru [26,54]. The binding energy of Ru0 3d5/2 in Ru/HZSM-5 was determined at 280.7 eV, which was relatively lower than that of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 around at 280.9 eV. A strong interaction might exist between metal Ru nanoparticles and Ga-HZSM-5, coinciding with the result of H2-TPR [37,55]. It could be inferred that there was an electron transfer effect between Ga-HZSM-5 and metal Ru, which could accelerate the H2 dissociation to release more active hydrogen radicals for improving the catalytic performance [56]. Furthermore, the research revealed that the doping of Ga in zeolite could increase oxygen vacancies, which facilitated to an improvement of active sites for reactants adsorbing on catalyst surface [57]. Similarly, Ga2O3 3d3/2 peak around 25.2 eV was also overlapped with O 2 s and thus difficult to recognize the binding energy of Ga2O3. Ga2O3 3d5/2 spectra in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 could be identified at the binding energy of 20.9 eV [58]. XPS analysis indicated that the active component in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5 was only metal Ru and Ga element existed in the form of Ga2O3 in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. The addition of Ga element could lead to the shift of Ru0 3d5/2 in Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 to a relatively high binding energy due to the formation of SMSI. SEM images in Fig. 5 showed that both HZSM-5 and Ga-HZSM-5 exhibited the regular shapes. HZSM-5 was composed of the discrete disc-shaped particles while Ga-HZSM-5 was composed of the discrete small spherical particles. Their particle sizes were only a few hundred nanometers and the surfaces were very rough due to the distribution of various pores. Similar shapes of reduced Ru/HZSM-5 and Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 could be clearly observed in TEM images (Fig. 5c and f). For the reduced Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, TEM analysis indicated that the average particle size of metal Ru was very small, only 3.20 nm (Fig. 5g and h). In addition, HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 5i) verified that metal Ru, the white bright spot marked with a red circle, was homogenously distributed on the surface of reduced Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. 3.2 HDO of DPE As summarized in Table 3, the HDO reaction of DPE could not occur at all at 1 MPa H2 when the catalyst was not added or support (HZSM-5 and Ga-HZSM-5) only existed. With the loading of Ru metal on supports, DPE was converted with varying degrees. The result showed that active metals were essential for the cleavage of C-O bonds in DPE. Under 1 MPa H2, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 exhibited the best performance that fully conversion of DPE and 100% selectivity of cyclohexane. Compared with conventional oxide supports such as γ-Al2O3 and SiO2, HZSM-5 with a relatively larger specific surface area and many midstrength acid sites possessed the higher activity and selectivity. Materials with large specific surface area were conducive to the dispersion of active metals and more midstrength acid sites promoted the removal of oxygen-containing species (OCSs). Both acidity and active metals were crucial in catalysts for HDO of DPE [27,30,64]. The activity and selectivity of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 were higher than that of Ru/HZSM-5, indicating that the doping of Ga in HZSM-5 framework significantly improved the catalytic performance. The doping of Ga not only enhanced the interaction between the metal Ru and the support to facilitate the H2 dissociation into active hydrogen radicals and the adsorption of reactants on the catalyst surface, but also increased midstrength acid sites of the catalyst to promote the removal of oxygen atoms. In order to illustrate the role of H2 in HDO of DPE, this reaction was carried out under 1 MPa Ar. Extremely low DPE conversion and cyclohexane selectivity were found over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5. The result demonstrated that H2 provided the main hydrogen source for HDO of DPE. In this case, when the pressurized H2 was used in HDO reaction, it was dissociated to form the highly active hydrogen radicals under the action of active metals [65]. Subsequently, the generated hydrogen radicals went through two major routes: (i) removing the chemically bonded oxygen in the form of H2O; (ii) undergoing the aromatic ring hydrogenation to generate saturated cycloalkanes [12,66–68]. Compared with the reports in Table 4, the reaction conditions of this work for HDO of DPE were milder, exhibiting the higher catalytic performance of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. In addition to H2, the solvent effect was also an important factor for HDO. As listed in Table 5, the high activity and selectivity were achieved in general alkanes solvents, while the poor catalytic performance appeared in common alcohol solvents and water. On one hand, the solubility of H2 in these alkanes was higher than that of alcohols and water, resulting in faster H2 dissociation into active hydrogen radicals to promote the cleavage of C-O bonds and the removal of oxygen atoms. On the other hand, the hydroxyl groups in alcohols could also undergo the HDO reaction, leading to the formation of competitive adsorption on the catalyst surface with DPE. The two main factors made alkanes the preferred solvent for HDO [69–71]. Among these alcohol solvents, DPE could be better converted with isopropanol used as the solvent, which might be the fact that isopropanol underwent the dehydrogenation reaction easily to provide a small amount of hydrogen source [21,72]. Therefore, the following reactions were all investigated under H2 atmosphere with n-hexane as the solvent. As shown in Fig. 6, as the increase of reaction temperature, the conversion of DPE and selectivity of cyclohexane gradually increased, while the selectivity of intermediate products including benzene, phenol and cyclohexanol all gradually decreased. For Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, DPE was completely converted at 180 °C and the product was cyclohexane without other by-products. 86.6% DPE conversion was obtained at 190 °C for Ru/HZSM-5. Although the selectivity of cyclohexane increased from 49.1% to 86.0% with raising the temperature from 150 to 190 °C, some intermediate products still existed. This indicated that 180 °C was favor for DPE to undergo the HDO reaction for Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 but not sufficient for Ru/HZSM-5. DPE could be completely converted only at a high temperature over Ru/HZSM-5. Compared with previous reports [27,31,59–61,73] at a much high temperature, the performance in HDO of DPE was better only at 180 °C and over bi-functional Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. In order to further illustrate the internal reaction pathways and product distribution, the kinetic behaviors were conducted under different reaction time as displayed in Figs. 6b and 6d, respectively. Zero hour meant that the reaction was stopped immediately after it rose from room temperature to 180 °C. It could be observed that when reaction time was 0 h, the conversion of DPE reached 45.3% and 13.5% over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 and Ru/HZSM-5, respectively, indicating that part of DPE was quickly converted during the heating process. Especially in the presence of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, the reaction could occur easily. The main products were benzene, phenol, cyclohexane and a small amount of cyclohexanol. In a very short time (0 h), the selectivity of phenol and benzene reached the maximum value, and the selectivity of cyclohexane and benzene was significantly greater than that of phenol and cyclohexanol. The result revealed that DPE mainly underwent the direct cleavage of C-O bonds to produce benzene and phenol, then benzene was further hydrogenated to form cyclohexane, and phenol underwent deoxygenation and hydrogenation to form cyclohexane. After the C-O bonds cleavage of DPE, the coexistence of rapid hydrogenation and deoxygenation reactions guaranteed the highest cyclohexane selectivity. The selectivity of benzene was higher than that of phenol due to the faster conversion of phenol to cyclohexane than the hydrogenation of benzene. Further extension of reaction time, the conversion of DPE gradually increased while the selectivity of benzene, phenol and cyclohexanol gradually decreased and finally disappeared at 2 h over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. In this case, neither the DPE conversion nor cyclohexane selectivity reached the maximum value over Ru/HZSM-5, showing the higher activity of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. Fig. 7a and c showed that the relatively low H2 pressure (0.1 MPa) resulted in a low activity. An increase of H2 pressure led to a sharp increase of DPE conversion and cyclohexane selectivity. In particular, both DPE conversion and cyclohexane selectivity reached a maximum value of 100% only at 1 MPa H2 over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. The condition required to achieve complete DPE conversion and 100% cyclohexane selectivity over Ru/HZSM-5 was 2 MPa H2. Compared with Ru/HZSM-5, the HDO reaction condition of DPE was milder over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 due to the introduction of Ga element. And other catalytic systems [27,60] reported that apart from the higher temperature in the HDO reaction of DPE, the required H2 pressure was also higher such as up to 5 MPa, demonstrating a higher advantage of this work. As depicted in Fig. 7b, the DPE conversion and cyclohexane selectivity gradually increased with an increase of the ratio of catalyst/substrate (C/S) over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, and finally reached a maximum value of 100% only at the ratio of C/S of 0.15. The DPE conversion and cyclohexane selectivity presented the same trend, but did not reach the maximum value even with a ratio of C/S of 0.20 over Ru/HZSM-5 in Fig. 7d. Less catalyst provided fewer active sites for HDO, which also suggested that the activity of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was higher than Ru/HZSM-5 under the same reaction conditions. To evaluate the recyclability and stability of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 catalyst, four consecutive cycles for DPE conversion were carried out at 150 °C and 1 MPa H2 for 2 h with n-hexane as the solvent. As shown in Fig. 8, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 catalyst could be reused at least for four cycles without the obvious change in the conversion of DPE and distribution of the main product cyclohexane. No significant change could be observed between the fresh and spent Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 catalyst, as characterized by XRD, XPS and TEM (Figs. S1–S3). Moreover, the Ru metal leaching was less during the recycling test by ICP as listed in Table S1. The result clearly indicated that the Ru supported on Ga-doped HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the excellent stability in HDO of DPE. 3.3 Reaction pathway for HDO of DPE Combining the experimental results and previous literature [30,73], the possible pathway for HDO of DPE over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was summarized in Fig. 9. The main reaction path was that DPE first underwent a direct hydrogenolysis reaction to generate benzene and phenol. Then benzene was further hydrogenated to produce cyclohexane and phenol was also converted to cyclohexane through hydrogenolysis and hydrogenation. In the initial stage of the reaction, a small amount of DPE could be detected through aromatic ring hydrogenation to produce CPE and OCE. Therefore, the minor reaction path was that a small amount of DPE first conducted aromatic ring hydrogenation to produce CPE and OCE, and then they were further converted into cyclohexane. Eventually, DPE was completely converted to cyclohexane. In the whole process, the C-O bond cleavage of DPE and subsequent aromatic ring hydrogenation were mainly controlled by highly active metal Ru while the acidic Ga-HZSM-5 was mainly responsible for the removal of oxygen atoms [10,60]. The doping of Ga element could optimize the catalyst structure and improve the HDO performance. 3.4 Scope of substrates for HDO To further investigate the scope of the application of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, the HDO reactions of more complicated lignin model compounds were carried out. From the results in Table 6, all reactants were completely converted under the conditions studied, demonstrating the high activity of the catalyst. Typically, for the reactants of cyclohexanol (entry 1), phenol (entry 2), DPE (entry 3, 4-O-5), 4-phenoxyphenol (entry 4, 4-O-5) and phenetole (entry 5), the only product cyclohexane with 100% selectivity was obtained. Only methylcyclohexane and toluene were detected as the major products for the conversion of 4-tolyl ether (entry 6, 4-O-5) and dibenzyl ether (entry 9). Despite the presence of incompletely hydrogenated toluene, the absence of OCSs revealed that the catalyst also exhibited a better deoxygenation effect on both reactants. The result in the literature [74] reported that the complete deoxygenation of dibenzyl ether could be achieved at 1 MPa H2 and 260 °C for 3 h with Ru/C and H3BO3 as the catalysts, indicating that the reaction conditions in this system were milder. In contrast to 4-O-5, the HDO of benzyl phenyl ether (entry 7, α-O-4) and phenylethyl phenyl (entry 8, β-O-4) gave quite different product distributions. Particularly, cyclohexane, cyclohexanol, methylcyclohexane and toluene were detected as the major products for the conversion of benzyl phenyl ether while cyclohexane, benzene, cyclohexanol and ethylcyclohexane for phenylethyl phenyl. The predominant oxygen-free compounds in products showed that Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 was also applicable for removing oxygen of the two reactants under mild conditions, which was comparable with other reported catalytic systems, such as Ru/H-ZSM-5 [27] and Pd/C and H-ZSM-5 [60], at a much higher temperature (200 °C or above) and a higher H2 pressure (5 MPa). Accordingly, the prepared Ru supported on Ga-doped HZSM-5 might be a promising catalyst for the conversion of different lignin model compounds. 3.5 HDO of lignin Inspired by the excellent performance of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5, the depolymerization reaction of real lignin was tested under the reaction conditions. As shown in Table S3, a low total liquid yield of 22.7% after lignin conversion was obtained with the absence of the catalyst while a high total liquid yield of 59.5% was achieved with the addition of Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. The catalyst not only promoted the depolymerization of lignin, but also had a remarkable impact on the product distribution after the reaction. The products could be divided into three main parts: aliphatic hydrocarbons, OCSs and other nitrogen- and sulfur-containing species. However, for better analysis, the types of resulting products were subdivided into six parts: aromatics (label 1), six-membered aliphatic hydrocarbons (label 2), other aliphatic hydrocarbons (label 3), phenolic species (label 4), other OCSs (label 5) and other species containing nitrogen and sulfur (label 6). From the results in Fig. 10, it was observed that OCSs were the main component in products without the catalyst and the total relative content reached 74%, of which the relative content of phenolic species was 21.19%. The total relative content of aliphatic hydrocarbons was up to 25.57%, of which 5.93% aromatics, 0.51% six-membered aliphatic hydrocarbons and 19.13% other aliphatic hydrocarbons existed. In addition, there were a small amount of other nitrogen- and sulfur-containing species with a relative content of only 0.43% in products. Compared with the blank experiment, the HDO of lignin over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 resulted in a fairly different product distribution. The total relative content of OCSs in products was extremely low, in which there were no phenolic species and only 0.96% other OCSs. Meanwhile, aliphatic hydrocarbons occupied the main components, of which 44.98% aromatics, 7.93% six-membered aliphatic hydrocarbons and 45.72% other aliphatic hydrocarbons were present. And there were also only 0.41% other nitrogen- and sulfur-containing species in products. The obtained products from lignin contained a large amount of OCSs such as phenolics under the reaction conditions without the acidic catalysts, while the products were mainly composed of aliphatic hydrocarbons such as aromatics in these systems with the acidic catalysts [10,54,75,76]. The results showed that Ru supported on Ga-doped HZSM-5 catalyst could effectively convert lignin to produce oxygen-free compounds. 4 Conclusions Ru supported on Ga-doped HZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by combining the in-situ synthesis and incipient wetness impregnation methods. Obtained Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 could completely convert lignin-derived DPE to generate the only product cyclohexane under mild conditions (180 °C, 1 MPa H2 and 2 h). The main reaction pathway was the direct hydrogenolysis of DPE and subsequent hydrogenation/deoxygenation. The doping of Ga obviously enhanced the interaction between the metal Ru and the support, which was conducive to promote the dispersion of Ru, improve the acidity of the catalyst and modify the electronic state of Ru. Further researches revealed that the oxygen atoms in lignin model compounds could be removed well via the HDO over Ru/Ga-HZSM-5. In the depolymerization of real lignin, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 not only significantly improved the total liquid yield, but also converted OCSs into oxygen-free aliphatic hydrocarbons. Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 exhibited the superior catalytic performance for the HDO of lignin and its model compounds, providing a new method for the sustainable production of value-added biofuels and chemicals. coredata.dc:description: Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of lignin to value-added biofuels and chemicals has a great significance for the advanced utilization of renewable lignocelluloses and the future biobased economy but is always a big challenge. Herein, a Ga-doped HZSM-5 supported metal Ru catalyst (bifunctional Ru/Ga-HZSM-5) exhibited the excellent HDO performance for converting diphenyl ether (DPE) to produce the only product, i.e., cyclohexane, under extremely mild conditions (180 °C, 1 MPa H2 and 2 h). The oxygen-containing group in DPE was mainly removed through the cleavage of the C-O ether bond, followed by metal- and acid-catalyzed comprehensive hydrogenation and deoxygenation. Further characterization results confirmed that the doping of Ga remarkably enhanced the interaction between the metal Ru and the support. For the depolymerization of real lignin, Ru/Ga-HZSM-5 could not only significantly improve the total liquid yield of lignin, but also convert the oxygen-containing species into the aliphatic hydrocarbons.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodeoxygenation of lignin and its model compounds to hydrocarbon fuels over a bifunctional Ga-doped HZSM-5 supported metal Ru catalyst
